# CHI-SQUARE GENERATOR
In breaking vigenere ciphers, it is a common practice to use the chi-square method in finding the encryption keys. This program takes in a string, and computes the chi-square value for each character in the English aplhabet. The closest value to zero is most likely the best key.

## Prerequisites
You should be familiar with Vigenere ciphers, or other encryption methods like Ceaser or Affine Ciphers. Else, this won't make sense to you.

To get a full vigenere cipher breaker example, check out [crypto.tosinsoremekun.com](https://crypto.tosinsoremekun.com).

## Example
Let's take a cipher text
```

```

From [Kasiski examination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasiski_examination), we know that our GCD is 4, hence we transpose the cipher text into 4 rows. We should have something like this;

| Y<sub>n</sub> | Substring |
|---------------| :-------------|
| Y<sub>1</sub> | GRHBFNQYNFVNQABMRZNARAQLYPVUUYERZIQRNFRZYGEVYRRSQRSGAGESRGUUVIFQFBNONVUUGRABRQCFUGYRFERBANYUUPBRFRNGNBRLSBERNENOBYYRVBZBZGNLFGJHZAGGGVBVZAAPNNSFZFORRGCOERZXZVRQFYENUUHLGBBAGJRPHNEEGNGNVJJIERNRUGANBZVINEBQFZABFABFFVEPAPVAOBBEFGBUERFPRQPRAHLRECVYCVGZVBVYCVGFGRERNAQUTNBRAVYNABRPARYNGBSAVEOYGVFPBNT |
| Y<sub>2</sub> | VGOBFZPOBJRQIPFVOABHGUSWCBQOSRGBCOHHHHJOMVFCOGBHOFPZRVGWFFSSGSCFCFKMZBOOAGGFACSCOKAGSCFRRHCSSOHHHJESJZFDSFOFBCZIWSMHBGHBWWZVSVSZOSVQFQBFGQKVFZKSPOFTGCSSSSMSCTGWFZSJSWFWHIAMVORVZJSFVZOBUVSSSBQWWVHQBOBWZOBSWOUQSSQDCSCSCCBRMBGAHCWWCAHCNGSMHOAFSVQMCPVOHBQMCPVVRFGBBUTHWQZFRRZHOICHOFPIVGFWGSSSOUHCTM |
| Y<sub>3</sub> | UYJIUBOJTYBJFOJQSETUJKHDWEUJIYQEJJEHZEUYRUQDIIJXDIQURUUDUQHOSHKUDKQHYWJJQIUJJTDDJYQUVJIEJQVEHDYXEUKRUTCHHKJJXYBJDITHWJXSDTBYBKSTWMEEQJQSJUXQCBXCUHQBQFUVJDCILJEUUORUDIUIXJUEUDUMTUVUQBDTXQXXJYQDSUUJEDTTBJQSEAFUIFUUBHTIKCJUDUJYHQTIRZQHTYJSKBQUQOQYIBUAUEQYIBUEUJJITQYYIXTIYKOYBHVYVQUIUJKDIJQQIXXIIY |
| Y<sub>4</sub> | CDSKMOZYKFIOYMOFYXSBSXVQSDDDYOBDSOBOEBXXISDKCWYOQYDKISVDCDDNYKXKDXIOJDGSUOPRYONGSVUXYRDKRVDDCXMSYXSBCSKODXRROMIZDCSIDOOYQOLWPCYSSSEXNSMEKSSXIYYOBOFODCNYROKKORVBKKBDDCVXOMKPWDKYRZONDCNPDDKORCCGRSBSPISEISVSXSBCYBCBNZEKDOONYWKOIFDZVECDSXRKCVUDDCVWCOIOMWVWCOIYCORDSXQXOCSSFKBYMCKYDVMOMYXQEYDCRKODDX |

We're a step closer to getting the encryption keys.

#### Finding Encryption Keys
Open `Vigenere.java`, and set the static string variable to the first substring. You should have this;

```java
    static String string = "GRHBFNQYNFVNQABMRZNARAQLYPVUUYERZIQRNFRZYGEVYRRSQRSGAGESRGUUVIFQFBNONVUUGRABRQCFUGYRFERBANYUUPBRFRNGNBRLSBERNENOBYYRVBZBZGNLFGJHZAGGGVBVZAAPNNSFZFORRGCOERZXZVRQFYENUUHLGBBAGJRPHNEEGNGNVJJIERNRUGANBZVINEBQFZABFABFFVEPAPVAOBBEFGBUERFPRQPRAHLRECVYCVGZVBVYCVGFGRERNAQUTNBRAVYNABRPARYNGBSAVEOYGVFPBNT"
```

Then run the program. We should have something like this;
![screenshot](https://tosinsoremekun.s3.eu-central-1.amazonaws.com/Screen+Shot+2019-11-14+at+1.24.04+PM.png)

Clearly, The best key is `13`or `N` in the English alphabet.

Repeat the process for the other 3 substrings. You should get `14 or O`, `16 or Q`, and `10 or K` respectively.

Most likely, our keys descryption keys are `N O Q K` or `[13,14,16,10]`.

#### Decrypting the Cipher Text
Open `Message.java`. Set the message variable to the cipher text, and the keys array to our newly found keys.

```java
String message = "";

int[] keys = new int[]{13, 14, 16, 10};
```

Then run the program. We should finally have our decrypted string. 

```

```

Good Job!
